div.bibl: Russkaya Pochta, Nov. 7, 1917. A PERMANENT RUSSIAN THEATRE IN CHICAGO

body.p: This is the third time that we write about the permanent Russian theatre. We have found out from definite sources that the mistaken course of the theatre is being changed.
The theatre is re-organizing along entirely different lines, this on the basis of an honest, modest Russian theatrical enterprise.

So, at least we believe we have now in our colony at the head of the administration a person with a good theatrical name, Mr. Klekner. The name of Klekner is familiar to the theatrical colony of Chicago, both for his parts in plays, and for his staging of them.

Beginning next week our Russian permanent theatre will appear before the Chicago public in a re-organized form. From next week, plays of a Russian repertoire will be performed. A. P. Chekhov, the great Russian
author and dramatist, will open the season period. On Monday and Tuesday "The Bear" will be performed. On Wednesday and Thursday, "The Proposal"; on Friday and Saturday, matinee and evenings, the four-act play, "The Living Corpses," which made a big hit in Russia, will be performed, the author of which is A. Evdokimov.
